awd_titl_txt: DCL: NSF INCLUDES The Technical and Human Infrastructure to Support Collective Impact of the INCLUDES Program at the Alliance and Network Levels
awd_abstract_narration:
As the NSF INCLUDES Program seeks to scale from the Launch Pilots to the full program, achieving its goals to promote the progress of science by broadening participation will rely on the ability to successfully scale the technical and human infrastructure for collaboration across the mini-backbones and the national backbone. The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) is seeking support for an NSF INCLUDES infrastructure conference that will provide a forum for discussion about current and long term technical and human infrastructure needs for scaling. Technical infrastructure might refer to the functions provided by any communication, community building and collaboration tool, such as document sharing or storage. Human infrastructure might refer to data analysts or community managers. 

The conference would include discussion of the structures and processes for creating a shared, overarching vision of the changes at all levels and for all groups that would be needed to promote the talent development goals envisioned within INCLUDES, supporting the current design and development launch pilots, and supporting scaling and promoting conditions for sustainability. Based on research on collective impact and improvement science in education, we would offer presentations followed by structured conversations within the setting of working sessions. The goals of AAAS for diversity and inclusion in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) are very much in keeping with the goals of INCLUDES; thus AAAS proposes to offer its existing online platform, Trellis, to support this comprehensive initiative to develop STEM talent from all sectors and groups in our society. 

The goals of the conference activity are to: (1) define short term and long term communications and networking needs that can support the pilots; (2) outline the technical specifications and human resources needed to support the pilots; (3) envision the technical, resource and human needs required to support Alliances; (4) develop design specifications for intra- and cross Alliance networking to support technical assistance, identification and curation of resources, support for communities of practice and capture of lessons learned and (5) propose tools, techniques, capacities and functionalities for an NSF INCLUDES National Network Backbone.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: American Association for the Advancement of Science
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF SCIENCE

por.por_cntn:
In 2016, the National Science Foundation (NSF) launched INCLUDES (Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science) as one of its “big ideas,” to expand the talent pool for STEM. In addition to providing support to a number of promising initiatives (design and development launch pilots) as planning grants and subsequently funding Alliances that emerged from these, NSF also funded conferences to explore many of the critical problems that would be faced by institutions and organizations as they came together to build out, implement and scale their ideas.

The American Association for the Advancement of Science received a conference grant: “The Technical and Human Infrastructure to Support Collective Impact of the INCLUDES Program at the Alliance and Network Levels” in 2016. The goals of the proposed conference were:

  • To discuss current and long term technical and human infrastructure needs for the NSF INCLUDES program.

This conference goal included exploring infrastructure needs at the project, Alliance and overall network levels. Technical infrastructure refers to the functions provided by any communication, community building and collaboration tool, such as document sharing or storage. Human infrastructure refers to the “people needs,” including data analysts or community managers.

  • To discuss the structures and processes for creating a shared, overarching vision.

This goal included considering the changes needed at all levels and for all groups to promote the talent development goals envisioned within INCLUDES, supporting the design and development launch pilots, and supporting scaling and promoting conditions for sustainability.

The conference was held at AAAS Headquarters in April 2017. The agenda was informed by a pre-meeting survey that laid out major issues being confronted by the funded pilots. To support intellectual merit, the issues included the need for strategies to establish a shared vision among widely diverse audiences within the pilots; different levels of technical know how and access among pilot members; sharing difficult conversations and building working relationships within teams. We were able to build on the research on team science and the practices emerging from the field of science community engagement management.

With many of the more than 70 conference participants attending from the local geographic area, sufficient funding remained in the grant to support a pre-conference workshop on this topic for a subsequent cohort of design and launch pilots prior to the May 2019 NSF INCLUDES Network convening.

In support of broader impacts, the emergence of the pandemic in early 2020 created new urgency in addressing communication needs of the organizations and institutions trying to bring onboard new Alliances. This led AAAS to work with NSF program officers for a re-scoping of the grant to allow us to assist two different cohorts of Alliance planning grant awardees in addressing the communications challenges of operating within a totally virtual setting. Separate sessions held in May 2020 and December 2020 gave planning grant awardees access to people (NSF INCLUDES program officers, NSF INCLUDES Hub staff, engagement experts, Alliance leaders) and opportunities for exchanging ideas and project plans with each other as they explored strategies for short- and long-term communications and networking needs.

Approximately 200 people benefited from the multiple rounds of engagement supported by this grant.

 



 


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Shirley M Malcom
